title: Long days but with fun people
content: The job can definitely be tedious most of the time. It’s a lot of repetitive work, but the people have been incredible to work with. So if you’re okay with lots of typing and starting at screens and love to do that around fun and energetic like minded people, then I’d say this job is for you.

title: Terrible work environment, Long random hours
content: You essentially walk in every day not knowing when you will be allowed to leave. The people in charge of your shift have no idea what will be sent down to them and in turn down to you. You can be left waiting for up to an hour just to hear if you are clear to leave.
cons: Time, Well being, instruction is none existent.

title: Long hours with no compensation...
content: Started around a year ago now and I simply cant keep going with it.Not compensated well, Largely forgotten about, communication isnt good among the teams.For the most part, Theres no real motivation to try with this job when youll eventually be let go anyways due to a contractual agreement.
pros: Free Lunch, Time off is super easy to get, Relaxed Work Environment, Nice People
cons: Long hours, mentally draining, No motivation, Not good benefits

title: I guess if you really love CoD
content: I was excited to start working in the gaming industry - ATVI ruined that excitement. Very poor communication, treated testers with no respect, revolving door of idiots. I made some friends, I learned some things, but the job, to me, was generally torture.
pros: Sometimes free food and swag, making friends
cons: constant random OT, bro culture, feeling like a tiny cog

title: Ehh
content: Good enough part time gig. Time crunching mostly, and the work environment was very negative to any women, especially anyone who was semi attractive at least.

title: Impossible to get promoted
content: You do the work of a level way above you only to get paid pennies for what you're achieving. There is also a culture of lower employees being overworked and promised certain benefits (pay raises/promotions/etc) only to find themselves doing the work and two years later, not getting what they were promised. Additionally, there's a pattern of mass employee exits and ZERO backfill, leaving those left behind to pick up a ton of work, which isn't doable or feasible.
pros: If you have a good manager, it helps things a LOT. The people are extremely kind.
cons: Tons of re-orgs, upper management is a mess (don't listen to employees at all), impossible to get promoted

title: Toxic Work Environment
content: Prejudiced atmosphere, favoritism, nepotism, violence in the workplace, poor management. An overall horrible place to work. If you are a self thinking person and don't need to fit in, then this is not the place for you.

title: Fun place to work
content: I like working here because there are a wide variety of employees from all backgrounds with many of the same shared interests. I have made alot of friends during my time working here
pros: Free lunch, close to home, flexible with time off.

title: Below industry standard pay in the highest cost of living area in the country
content: you cannot afford to work at Blizzard... Everyone I worked with lived with 4-5 co-workers all together in small cramped housing or rental units. The pay is below industry standards and far below the area cost of living. Blizzard feels that it is such a priviledge to work at Blizzard that they can pay far below the gaming industry average salary for any and all positions at all levels. The pay is so far below the area cost of living that everyone who works at Blizzard is basically destitute, and that is considering the 80 hour work weeks with 16-20 hours 7 days a week especially during crunch times before game update release dates. The benefits are not worth the extra cost you have to pay in for.
pros: 16 hour average work days 7 days a week during crunch periods lasting for several months, poverty level pay for the area in Irvine California, Management staff are generally family members or friends with no previous management education, experience or training

title: Pretty Good
content: It's okay. Really repetitive and long hours of the same thing but it's testing video games so can't complain to much. If you like videos games and like to hear about the new stuff coming out go for it.

title: Nepotism galore at Blizzard
content: It's not what you know, it's who you know. Lots of a** kissing at Blizzard to be part of the circle. It's a boys club. Developers are well taken care of. If you are NOT a developer/designer directly making products, you are a step child and expendable. Look elsewhere.

title: Great place to work, but don't expect to move up
content: Amazing culture, fun loving people. Only drama you'll find is the drama you make. Work load however it's quite heavy. But they care for your well being... Until the end of your contact. Then you're cut off right away. It's an amazing job until your contract ends
pros: Free snacks and drinks, decent pay
cons: Lots of hours, but if you need a sick day, they'll never say no

title: Lame
content: Lack of advancement, way to much overtime demanded, pay is a joke, always be a contractor not a full time employee, full time employee will physical abuse you.

title: a full of liars
content: You'd need to work overtime all the time but never get paid for itDo not believe what they say in the hiring processThey do not reimburse expenses for devicesTerrible management

title: Ok
content: If you plan to make this a temporary job its not meant for you nor a career... But i do recommend to all that are so passionate and hard workers that are experienced at what they do work smarter not harder the pay wasnt good for me but i enjoyed working there i can only imagine what my pay would look like if i got payed more by the hr

title: Pretty Fun and Relaxed while also Productive
content: Most average work days were pretty nice and i enjoyed them as a member of the night shift. Everyone got along great and helped each other out, the complaint would be unexpected overtime, as in expected to stay because of emergency test got planned 5 minutes before shift ended. Otherwise they REALLY care about you there and always willing to help anyway they can.
pros: Free Lunches at least once a month, TV and game systems in break room, Lots of Overtime possibilities
cons: Healthcare can be hard to contact through third party, Can be hard to contact using person email, Unexpected Last Minute shift extensions

title: Good place to start job career in Ireland
content: As one of the first places to work once you arrive in Ireland, Activision is a good place to get started. Culture is nice but benefits are super limited.

title: Fresno location was wonderful
content: I enjoyed coming to work every day. Management cared, and that made it easy to want to excel. Several perks, including free games. Good hours, minimal weekends.

title: Unprofessional dream killer
content: Its a contract job for people with dreams of game development. It takes advantage of people by giving them expensive insurance and poor wages. They justify low pay by giving their employees merchandise.The management is awful, they ignore office bullying despite being reported over 5 times. They come in late and scold you for being late. They get wasted and or high. They are down right disrespectful to employees.They will cater and hold various events for morale, even though they use that to justify their abuse.Overall, a poor contract job with rude management. And not high enough pay for the stress, and not enough to even pay rent. Will not work for again.
pros: Sense of accomplishment, no dress code.

title: Interesting co-workers, trying management.
content: As an easily replaceable quality assurance tester in the gaming industry, you will never be left wondering about your job security. You will see many groups of new testers appear and disappear at about the same pace.Expect constant surprise overtime and crunch times. You will not be able to have a life outside of work after the hard pace of the workflow and the demands.Employees are often like-minded and completely fun to talk to. Get used to this and take advantage of the lap as it will be your only outlet.Testing unreleased products is great, and it's very rewarding to see people's first look at something you've been working on for months.Treatment from low-level superiors is often lacking, expect to be treated as if you are in day care. Seniors constantly seem to have something to prove, and that 'something' is that they are better than you in all respects - right or wrong. You will not trust the full picture or even a third of the required information.In stark contrast, leadership is often much more relaxed and easy to get along with.This is not where your dreams of becoming a videogame developer will begin. This is where your dreams will go to die. To be crushed and siphoned from you to oil the great AAA machine.
pros: Coworkers are like minded, Being in the know is
cons: Work/life balance does not exist, Treatment from superiors is lacking at it's base, Compensation is less than competitive, Information mismanagement at all levels, Absolutely no trust, You are cattle

title: A fun place to work, but most likely will only work there temporary.
content: Overall I had a great experience at Activision, the only thing negative about working there is when you work 12 hour shifts. But other than that, the days flew by even during the 10 hour shifts. Plus you get paid time and a half during overtime.
pros: Getting paid to play video games

title: Basically a sweatshop for gamers with high hopes...
content: They send in herds of kids and drugdealers multiples times a month because everyone quits. Half of the staff is also high out of their minds or drunk..
pros: Easy to get drugs if your into that
cons: No work/life balance. Kids wear furry tails...

title: A very unique environment that I'm happy I got to work in.
content: Working QA at Activision wasn't like any other job that I had worked at or have worked at since. It honestly kinda felt like being part of a big awkward family, and not in that stupid corporate PR "family" sort of way. Things were generally pretty laid back and friendly and the managers got to know most of the employees that they frequently worked with on a fairly personal level. The only real problems that I had with the job were things like: you might not be making enough to make the job worth your while unless you are taking the absurd overtime hours, the majority of positions above your managers will treat you like dirt and only barely allot your managers any respect at that, and that the QA position is considered seasonal but they don't tell you when your last day is so you just end up wondering when your job is going to end instead of being able to plan around it.
pros: Sometimes offers free meals, good overtime pay, unique friendly work environment and culture, long breaks
cons: Rude higherups, never know what you are going to be doing when you come in, doesn't pay well without overtime

title: Overall a negative experience
content: I do not recommend anyone to work there.The salary is really low for a city like Dublin, contracts are temporary, max 18months. Career growth is non existant, they pretend like everyone has a chance when it's really all about those already permanent.Expect to work weekends and banks holidays. Management is really really bad, they treat people poorly, especially temporary testers. So many more problems there, management made it a really toxic place to work, it's a factory, where you don't matter at all,I do not recommend.

title: Fun working place good working with coworkers
content: A typical day at work would be that we were very busy everyday. What I learned was to be very responsible,careful and safety. The most enjoyable part about this job was that working with my fellow employees.

title: Fun workplace environment with fellow gamers!
content: - typical day of work: help answer tickets and learn more about the Player Support team - management was very nice and willing to teach us more about the industry - fun environment! Most fellow employees were also gamers and we got along really well, but they're also friendly if you're not a gamer! - awesome kitchen: free snacks and drinks! - kind of wish that we did more in-depth tasks but it was just a 3 month internship so I understand there's not much time for that

title: Fun workplace, heavy workload, testing great products.
content: Testing and ensuring that each video game title is release as cleanly as possible with as few bugs and errors as possible. Working together as a team to ensure proper programming and debugging.
cons: Heavy workload, sixty hours a week, strong need to meet deadlines.

title: Fun work environment with great management
content: A fun company to grow with and be a part of. Management that really understands family life and are very personable people who treat you more like a person than a number and also help you with typical questions one may have when new to video game testing. all in all a great company to work for.

title: fun place to work
author_type: SVP, Global Chief Information Officer, Head of Global Strategic Sourcing
content: Fun place to work, Great business, lot of opportunities, Great management and executive team, Global company, great culture, Entrepreneurship spirit, Fast Pace

title: Abandon all hope
content: One of the worst companies I've worked for and Quality Assurance is the epitome of a thankless job. The pay is terrible. They posted 7.5 billion dollars in 2018 and just recently increased tester salaries to a whole $12 an hour. There are signs at retail positions in my area for $14 - $15. That is how little the company values QA. Metrics are the name of the game yet QA employees are not rewarded for meeting miles stones with number of bugs submitted. Oh our bosses get reamed out when a critical showstopper is missed, who then in turn ream us out as a group, but catch something egregious just before a major games expo...Pat on the head and a "good job" Developers talk down to us in comments, insult our intelligence, and treat us as a nessecary evil. Burn out is common, turn over is huge. Good workers are rewarded with more responsibility for no extra pay. This adds to resentment, burn out and quitting. Bad workers are common and not fired nearly fast enough because you still need a crew to sail your ship even if the majority of them are useless. Don't come here thinking this is your "foot-in-the-door" like some many naive kids I see. You will never get out of QA. The CEO or some executive will never come over and see you doodling during your break and be so impressed by your subpar weeb drawings that you are elevated to a character artist. QA is where dreams and dreamers go to die. You could make lead, or project lead maybe. But the company has routinely laid off large groups of QA positions when profits didn't meet their unrealistic expectations. So even - more...

title: Great Coworkers.. Frustrating Job
content: QA testing at Activision involves some video game playing but mostly involves searching and writing bugs as well as marking off testing in lists and verifying bug fixes. It's an office job involving video games more than a job about playing video games. This job requires a lot of flexibility as communication from other offices can be sparse and unclear which can lead to a lot of waiting to be able to do things. What we are doing can be changed at a moment's notice. The overall organization can feel scattered and all over the place. What's more is, because our testing office is nearly constantly hiring, newer people always outnumber people who have been here a while. Many people pick up the job quite quickly, but the imbalance of new people unsure of how to do things leads to a lot of mistakes and things falling through the cracks. In many ways, it feels like more experienced testers still do the bulk of the work despite the ginormous team we have on staff. I have met a lot of really good people doing this job, some of which are the best coworkers I've ever had, but that doesn't make up for the daily frustrations of this job. We had been on crunch for 4 months (12hr days 6 days a week) and that wore everyone down substantially and eliminates any healthy work/home balance. There are some opportunities for advancement, but for the average tester, there is no hope of moving up even if you do a lot of the work people above you do already. Especially with the quantity of new people this can mean having more responsibilities and doing a lot more leading without a pay raise - more...

title: F air an perfessional
content: I loved working for this company the work was consistent never a time when you did not have something to do fast paste is my joy it make the time fly by the only thing I wished for was overtime

title: Fun environment, but the pay and hours are not for everyone
content: Depending on your project, you will find yourself working 12 hours a day, 6 days a week, for weeks or month prior to launch. The Leads are rather hands off, leaving things in the hands of senior testers. These senior testers are generally decent at delegation of tasks, but there were multiple instances of normal testers having to waste time due to their inefficiency at getting things done. 12 hour days would not be needed if the people in charge were more on top of getting things done. Overtime pay is nice, but the base pay leaves much to be desired.

title: Long days
content: Going to work every day knowing that they were 12 hours days All week and some times on Saturday. Great place to meet new people and unloading trails that come in

title: A pleasure to serve
content: A great company to work for in an amazing dynamic industry with tremendous potential. Opportunity abounds and it's truly a global organization offering great products.

title: Fun workplace overall.
content: In my specific group, work culture could be better. Need more collaboration between teams. Company, in general, is a fun work environment with like-minded workers.

title: Fun, easy if you like games. Terrible if you want to do more then just game.
content: Working here was mind dulling and repetitive with what work they give you. If you are a teenager and want to just play games for a living of 11$ an hour. great, you're set. If you want to move up in the community. Not a chance. Look to a different publisher.

title: Fun Place to work, with some big cons.
content: Working at Activision has to be the focus of your life. Working QA does not give the employee much notice, if any, for if work will be required on weekends. It was frequently required. It is a fun environment with enjoyable company and management. However, QAMN feels like it is seperated from the main Company of Activision. While the locational management is fantastic, the overall company seems to just have QA under their boot for whatever the whims of the developers are. If you do not have much else to do and would love to work with a fun group of people on fun projects then this is not bad. However if you have other things to do outside of work, it gets in the way of personal development.

title: This isn't a job its a death sentence.
content: If you're expecting your hard work to ever be rewarded stay far away. QA positions are still treated like an outsourced job, and management is too chicken to stand up to corporate to fix things. Contracted positions ensure that you never have job security and that you are expendable regardless of performance. Good for someone fresh out of high school since they'll take anything that breathes but otherwise stay away from this picture perfect example of corporate greed.
pros: Free terrible games. Great place to find friends that hate life as much as you.
cons: CONTRACTS you will never be a proper employee or be treated as anything more than outsourced labor.

title: Q & A Tester
content: Typical Day at Work: You worked on finding bugs and glitches most of the day. You got three breaks two shorter, one longer that were spaced really well. When you were feeling like you needed a break it was time for a break. What I learned: It's enjoyable to work as a Q & A Tester Management: Good overall, only negative was didn't really have flexible scheduling. Workplace Culture: Good Hardest Part of the Job: Getting used to the hours, I was night shift so I had to get used to staying up late. Most Enjoyable Part of the Job: Honestly everything else.

title: Passion
content: Building a video game is incredibly hard work. Lots of 100 hour weeks to finish a game, but if you loves the gaming it is worth all of the sacrifices in your personal life.

title: Austin's Customer Service center has a unique atmosphere.
content: Working at Activision Blizzard's Austin campus was a great experience, the atmosphere was like being with a family. Blizzard's always been overwhelmingly accepting to all woks of life. With how fun, friendly and accepting the fellow employees are, it almost makes up for the work load and the slightly lower pay compared to other like jobs. Working for a video game company; as Customer Service, you do interact with an interesting customer base. Being gamers, we're far more passionate about our games and interactions. Customer interactions tend to lean harder to both ends of the spectrum. You'll face as many un-fun contacts as the run of the mill every day contacts; great and impressionable contacts can be far and few between. Burn-out can be a real issue. Stress in the workplace is an on-going problem. When choosing the Austin campus, if you're wanting to work your way up the chain to non-Customer Service jobs. Making the step to Irvine is a great challenge and in some cases is impossible. Being so secluded from Head Quarters, networking can be a major challenge. Don't see Customer Service as 'getting your foot in the door'.
pros: Fan base, loot, healthcare, atmosphere, family and friends
cons: Low pay, heavy work load, burn-out, stress, seclusion from HQ

title: Long hours but very flexible, with incredible work environment and management.
content: A typical work day is 8:30am to 5:30pm or 5:30pm to 2:30am for night shift, Monday to Friday with varying weekend work. During crunch time for games, typically between June and December, the hours can become more prevalent and can increase to 6 days a week regularly. This job is very team oriented and you are always around other people in a bullpen style office. The work environment is very friendly and casual but professional with a focus on the current project. Project can be moved around a lot and requires you to remain on your toes and learn as you go. The hardest part for me personally was the crunch time hours in which the hours were increased dramatically but the overtime pay was well worth it. Management is very good as they higher internally from people that use to be in your position, so there is a better connection. Overall, if you are someone that has a lot of time to work, you enjoy gaming and working with people with the same passion as you to help make them work, then this is the place for you.
cons: Long hours, Small window for advancement, Job security

title: Cool chill atmosphere with way too much overtime
content: 64 - 69 hours of committed time per week for over month. Zero communication about how long to expect overtime to continue or what general expectations are. Sometimes they only give an hour's notice that the shift is being extended 2 or 3 hours.

title: Treat employees like their gamers...
content: ...unable to provide a clear summary at this time but hopefully the review summary will give a good enough indication of what it is like to work at AB

title: Frustrating and unorganized but a fun environment.
content: From my experience working at the Activision QA MN branch, I have had a lot of fun as well as experienced a lot of adversity. Entry level positions are all contract based, and with most contracts, temporary. Advancement opportunity is severely limited. It often feels as if it is not based on qualifications but whether or not management likes your personality. The hourly rate is very low as with most entry level jobs, which is understandable. However as it is contract, there is no chance for pay increase in relation to how well the job is done. So, someone who performs to the best of their ability is always going to be paid the same as someone who performs the bare minimum. So, treat the job for what it is. Temporary and used for experience. As it is a contract job, I have met a lot of new and interesting people who have come through the job. Coworkers are almost always friendly towards each other and finding new friends is fairly easy. Most people who work here are all into the video game scene so it is easy to spark new conversations. Direct management is always within reach as they are on the testing floor near the other testers at all times. An open door policy with higher management is in place making conversing with management very simple. Management is, for the most part, very helpful and nice towards testers. Of course, there's always going to be some abrasion, but that's something that comes with all jobs. HR is also always close by and more than willing to help which is very nice. Now, one part I do have to warn about, is the hours. Seeing as the primary - more...
pros: Fun and interesting job with a lot of nice people.
cons: The business plan doesn't feel 100% flushed out yet but has a lot of potential.

title: Friendly
content: New experience meet people I would Iike to go back and work at this environment again it was. Seasonal job to start and no experience needed to start.

title: Fun place to work at
content: It is a fun place to work out but also will keep workers occupied. There is plenty of downtimes but also plenty of time where everyone is working constantly.

title: Fun environment but advancement is questionable
content: Great coworkers and it's definitely a place I would stay long term if there was career advancement built into the role. Management changed often which throws everything into discord.
cons: 2 weeks vacation and 1 week company shut down last week of year

title: Incredible experience
content: Typical day on the job is high pressure to "break the game" Management was more than willing to answer any questions I had. The culture was what you'd expect; full of gamers. The hardest part of this job is during crunch time, you eat sleep and test the game which makes work/life balance difficult if you're a family man/woman. The most enjoyable part I found was getting an inside look at the video game industry and how it functions. Definitely a great experience if you're an avid gamer. Overall I'd say Activision/Blizzard is a great company to work for, upper management would always crack jokes and make it a fun environment to the best of their ability.
cons: Work/Life balance and Hourly pay without overtime.

title: Abandon all hope ye who enter here
content: You have to sign an NDA (Non-disclosure Agreement) that's so one-sided I'm surprised I didn't have to sign in blood. I'd go into detail but the NDA doesn't allow me to talk about my NDA...no, seriously. As a game tester you get to see the game in it's worst possible state. There will be days the game is barely functional and you are expected to just "deal with it". It can be incredibly frustrating at times. Mandatory overtime is to be expected and they are VERY upfront about that. During crunch, 12 hour shifts 6-7 days a week are common. Yes, you will be working every weekend from now until Ragnarok. I can't tell you the number of people that have quit because they didn't want to work the weekend. The company relies too heavily on metrics and unrealistic target predictions to make sure it's getting its money's worth. This causes everyone to "game the system" by writing up 100s of low priority bugs simply because they are easier to find and write. Management tries to help as best they can but has very little power/authority to make any meaningful changes. Company culture is CYA (Cover Your *ss). Doing the absolute minimum is what I've learned working here. There is no incentive to go the extra mile, you won't be rewarded. You are contract and thus will NEVER get a raise. You will also be making the same as the worst/laziest tester. Good employees are rewarded with more work and responsibility for the same wage. During high turn-over periods almost anyone is accepted as long as they have a pulse. Many of the people that work here play too many games and don't - more...
cons: Unrealistic demands, low wages, no advancement, noise, unprofessional environment

title: Productive
content: It was fun at times and easy at times was really fast paced under staft management was poor unfair treatment depending on nationality leads did very little to help workers leads were always right according to management supervisors alike

title: Very Nice Staff but Work/Life Balance is desperately lacking.
content: Prior to all releases and launches, most employees will end up working 12+ hours per day up to 7 days per week, not allowing much time outside of work. However, that being said, most of the staff is very nice and friendly to be around for these long hours.
cons: Low pay for the amount of work completed.

title: It has been so long
content: I cannot really review Activision because it has been so long since I have been there and the company has changed so much over the last 20 years - I really cannot say much at this point

title: Amazing projects, but environment can be soul-sucking
content: Activision is like business school on steroids. It can be very motivating because the business sets goals, sticks to its mission and wins. You will learn a ton. But internally it is driven heavily by politics, certain teams carry far more sway than others, and decisions definitely are being made in "the meeting after the meeting." Culture can be especially hard for women - very few are in leadership roles and the company's values tend to promote combativeness and aggression. The company does attempt to acknowledge successes and offer rewards to lower-level employees who are outperforming expectations but the company could do better. Some of the creature comforts are cool - everyone gets video game consoles and TVs on their desks, there are free snacks, and the company does lots of happy hours and parties.

title: Great IP to be involved with low engagement from managers and office
author_type: MBA Film & TV Business Strategy Intern
content: For a studio spun-off from a gaming company its a surprisingly non-gamer community; like most production companies ABS is a small unit on no-nonsense executives and their assistants. Collaboration and interaction is somewhat low and work is a lot slower than a traditional production company as much is being developed in-house.
cons: short breaks, little interaction between co-workers

title: Great Company with some not so great Teams
content: Great company but definitely has some holes as expected. My experience is among bad leadership but this encounter is an isolated situation which does not reflect the company as a whole.
pros: Benefits, Happy Hours, Great Parties, Fun environment

title: A great experience, I'd love to work there full time.
content: My time as a Summer intern at Activision/Blizzard was an incredible experience. I was a customer service representative there, and I learned how to work with a team of like minded individuals to meet our goals. The hardest part of the job was going back home at the end of the summer.

title: You will get exploited
content: Very poor working conditions, exploitation at its finest. Shame on Activision for running the Localizations office as a sweat shop. People were amazed to hear that such high profile company would treat their employees this way.
pros: You get to learn curse words in other languages
cons: Work in shifts, work on weekends compensated as regular days, parking provided to top management only, AC shut down on weekends to save costs

title: Distribution Center
content: I worked at a distribution center, not the head quarters, so it was a dirty dark facility that no longer exists. The facility was closed in February 2018.

title: Very social work place
content: Work is easy but fast paced and competitive. Employees are very social and kind. Days go quick and are not tiring at all. Culture is productive and easy going.

title: no advancement
content: not a career to stay in for a long period of time. 40 hours a week with minimum wages. a good place for a summer job, but wont be able to support long terms financial responsibilities. but with the right crew any fun.

title: A fantastic work environment with excellent managers
content: The culture at Activision is one that I dare say could be rarely rivaled; extremely competent managers who genuinely want the best for each employee. The most rewarding part of working at Activision has been the plethora of opportunities to grow my skill as a concise writer as well as bolstering my ability to efficiently grasp make quick decisions in heated times.
pros: Very accepting work culture, occasional free meals, and bi-weekly in house events.

title: Meh
content: The good things: The people I work with and management are all pretty cool. The job is easy and you're paid to game all day. It's a fun environment. The bad things: They request people with an education and totally low ball them regardless of how high of an education they have. They do not take that into consideration when it comes to compensation for working there. Permanent positions are rare and hard to come by.

title: My time at activision
content: work long hours and for little pay, but the job and the people there were great, i would recomend this job to anyone who has a love for video gaming and would like to know more about the behind the scenes aspects of the video game culture

title: all I am missing is a brand to make me an activision cattle
content: if you like being treated like cattle, work here. you dont even feel like a human worker when employed here. treated like a dime a dozen. seen hard workers there for 10+ years and never got a promotion or raise.

title: Awesome day at Activision
content: Typical day at work walking in to work everyone smiling an talking an getting settled in. I learned how systems are boxed an processed and organized thanks to our Management this are set up pretty nice and in order . They are very helpful they wont leave your side until your sure. . The hardest part of the job is standing on your feet all day an doing the same thing over and over.you may get a little ditsy but The most enjoyable part was coming into work feeling blessed to have a job an me an my co-workers motivating each other to be there every day .

title: production worker was a great job
content: There were slow days and busy days. it was great working as a production line. also working as a sit down forklift driver and working at distribution worker at Blizzard. as a order picker and rf scanner. I also learned how to work together as a group to be number one at all times.

title: Not for the feint of heart
content: Overall, some of the smartest people I've ever worked with worked at this organization. If you want to get an MBA-level education without spending the money, working there gives you a ton of cool opportunities to learn. You will also likely work harder and longer than you have in other parts of your career. It's a great proving ground to test your mettle.

title: Fast paced and people friendly
content: Recommend for anyone who lives in the immediate area. Great entertainment company with continuous growth opportunity in the gaming and esport industry.

title: One of the best company to work with
content: One of the best company to work with, there are ample amount of scope to advance in your career growth. Colleagues and work culture are most appealing part of the company. Ther work hard and party harder.

title: Great Experience
content: Working for the game industry gives you a wonderful bit of insight into how it works. It is also a very 'ebb and flow' business model so job security can be scary.

title: Its not work if you're doing what you love.
content: Not the greatest pay to start but lots of available overtime to make up for it. Not hard work if you have the right mind for it. Management knows how long a tiresome the process can get and do anything they can to boost moral. free food frequently, and lots of promotional products for game as they come out, movie screenings, and plenty of casual hang out time to relax. its a lot of work and very high competition for positions but they make you feel like your part of something and its more like hanging out with friend than dealing with coworkers.
pros: Great environment, great people, great perks.
cons: - Contract positions, nothing full time. Unpredictable schedule with long hours up 7 days a week in crunch time.

title: Activision Blizzard
content: Working at Activision Blizzard was a blast. The hours are long but your surroundings are very accommodating. The company is great to work for, they take care of their employees very well.

title: Waste of time and opportunity
content: Being able to play video game from time to time was great. The free snack and drink was okay too. The best reward you get for working hard is the survival of time-based layoff. This job sucks.

title: It was a pretty good place to work
content: In general it’s a pretty good place to work. Most mangers are nice as well as most of the people. Some mangers play favorites for moving people to DLC.

title: Productive and fast pace.
content: The culture of place was good. Their wasn't to hard projects to do. The most enjoyed part of the day was specking with my co workers. Has far has management they were extreme fair.

title: Administrative Support - Overall Satisfaction
content: Fun company to work for. Company runs lean, hard work/long hours is the expectation. Slightly above average compensation, benefits. Perks make up the difference. Company culture is work hard, play hard.

title: QA Shop is fun for first job
content: Activision is a ton of fun to work for. This job is not for people who are late in their careers and looking for a livable wage for a family or household, but more for someone just out of High School or summers in between college courses.
pros: Fun atmosphere, video games all day

title: Productive and fun Place to work at.
content: its a great place to be at. The work culture is great and there is a decent work/life balance. there are tons of fun opportunities while at work and a party on every game release.

title: Not what you think it would be
content: Oversee a team of 10-20, depending on the platform being tested. Writing and submitting daily and weekly reports directly to the producer. Delegate test case scenarios to various team members. Making deadlines.
cons: Long hours, low pay, limited mobility

title: Grueling and Rewarding
content: I found my time at Activision to be a mixed bag. I look back at my initial time there as some of the most formative, "Golden Age" times of my life. I worked with quality people and I enjoyed coming to work each day. As time moved on and the work changed, so did priorities and the atmosphere. Work became more of a slog and i started to enjoyed the people I was working with and for less and less. Eventually, it became to much stress for not enough pay, and I was literally sleeping under my desk and working for works on end consecutively on a regularly basis. It can be a reward place to work if you are ambitious and willing to sacrifice a lot for the job. If not it is hard to recommend.
cons: Long Hours, Lack of Compensation and Recognition, No Work/Life Balance

title: Exhausting
content: Great place to connect with other Video Game lovers. Many friends have been made throughout my 2 years there. However, there is no room for advancement and you will barely see life outside of work.

title: Menial and Unrewarding
content: Upper management only cares about the numbers. Only one aspect of the project is noted by upper management, but many parts are required to deliver a finished product. Direct managers are at least competent.

title: Awesome environment / Low pay
content: Blizzard is a company I could see myself working for my whole life, but only if I was able to find a better type of job within the company as well as better pay. This is a video game company and the atmosphere matches what you'd expect. It's very laid back and people can be themselves. In fact, it's encouraged. The only two things that drove me away are the pay and the type of work I was doing. I was a customer service representative. Most of the time, you only get to talk to customers that are upset about something, so you need to be someone with a very strong willingness to help, but also very thick skin. The pay was also fairly typical for customer service. You'd only be able to earn a decent salary if you managed to work your way up the ladder to a senior or management role, but you'd have to compete with a lot of other people to do so. There are other departments available, but many of them require the best of the best. You can get there, but it'll be a lot of work. I'd love to go back eventually. I got my 5 year sword, but I really wanted that 10 year shield!

title: Grinder
content: To put it simply, Activision's QA office is simply nothing more then a grinder. They bring in testers for their seasonal launch windows and then send them on their way. They require degree's for their minimal QA role and then pay on a scale of someone with no educational experience. You can expect extremely limited job advancement as there are only a handful of full time jobs available and they typically only go to those who have developed an 'in' with the management team. This is a job for those in a transitional period of employment.

title: The employee vibe was amazing.
content: The employees were wonderful to work with, but management would throw a wrench in the works daily. Sometimes impossible to recover from it. It made everyone question their abilities. Folks proffered not to speak to one another in fear of hearing it from someone that was not suppose to repeat it.
pros: Events were magnificent it was eat drink and be marry
cons: The red tape to get things done made one fail even if one was on point.

title: HR Rules the world-what they say goes
content: If you're on the right side with HR, you'll get ahead. If not, they may be limiting your growth potential. They have a lot of power, including with studios. The culture of each studio varies, so I would look at each studio to see what fits you. It's hard to advance if you're on the corporate side. The studio development side is different and there is more room for advancement.

title: Fast paced
content: It was a good job. I enjoyed working there, but at times it felt very fast paced and it was extremely hot in there. They did have lots of fans in there though to make it more bearable. They also gave you water bottles because of how hot it was.

title: Productive work
content: I liked it cause it was a fast paste environment and it made time go by faster. The pay wasn't so good but the hours were. I liked how we get to communicate with other workers while working in line and I liked how we rotate our positions.
pros: Get to talk while working in a fast paste.

title: All work and no play.
content: As a huge gamer, ironically I've never had such little free time to play games since working at Activision. The operations tempo and overall demand was ridiculous. Commonly, when ATVI would put on "fun" things for us, it was only the admin staff that had the time to partake. Us in the trenches had to skip the fun or try to get one of our finance buddies to grab us a free t-shirt or ice cream that was being handed out for no particular reason. Working at the main HQ the studios were treated like precious princesses that needed their every whim attended to. AP took a subservient approach to managing their dev ops. Our leaders never knew how to say no, no matter how crazy the request was from the studios. The studios would fall behind and we at the HQ would pay the price trying to play catch-up while in turn the studios would blame us for the overall delay. Pumping out a lame CoD game every year isn't working. Wake up ATVI.
cons: Long hours, no leisure time, horrible management

title: ATVI was a very energetic environment
content: ATVI was a fast and dynamic company. It was full of "career-minded" people that were highly inspired and mostly fun to work with. Employees were pushed and held accountable.
cons: Would have been nice to have more vacation time

title: Working in Tech Support can be really random.
content: Most days would be spent answering calls and e-mails sent by customers needing help. When there were neither calls nor e-mails, we could enjoy a few minutes playing any game the company made. The best part of the job was the challenge that comes with solving a person's problem. A lot of the information was easily found on our website, so it was mostly a matter of sorting through it all. The workplace was enjoyable. Being between the programmers and "the suits" of the company was enjoyable to get a taste of both serious sides of video games. When a game was being developed, we occasionally got to do a little Quality Assurance of the game, which is not as easy or as "fun" as it sounds to the average listener. It was not about "playing" the game as much as it was about trying to "break" the game. There are only two really negative parts to the job. When you're on a team were everyone has the same high expectations of their work, you get so much done that there are no e-mails left and you have to agree to wait your turn for a call. If even one person decides to be a slacker, it can slow everything down to a crawl. Also, the internship never grew in a paying job. When I would interview for a position, I would, instead, be offered another chance at the internship.
pros: Welcoming environment, great experince, free gameplay
cons: Varying levels of work everyday, Never offerd paid job

title: Stay Away!
content: Unless you are a gamer or desperate for any work, do not even think about working here! Very high turnover, back-stubbing and on-going threat of layoffs create a very toxic work environment.

title: Productive
content: I worked at a warehouse and as there temporary employee I was assigned to do the following: putting labels on boxes, stacking the boxes on pallets, receiving shipments, organizing the merchandise, put the merchandise back in to a box, and get the boxes ready to ship out.

title: Fun place to work and great people
content: This job was awesome because you get to play video games for a job. The only hard part was meeting the daily bug count towards the end of the project because there were not many left. The best part was just being able to play games. and the friendly co-workers.

title: Productive line
content: I package games Wii , Xbox , ps4 , I worked on the converted belt and stacked boxes 6 high and they had you move positions every 2 hours and they had 2 breaks and 1 lunch break
cons: You had to stand the entire shift

title: Great place to work
content: Great place to work, very busy, allowed you to work on your own. Management was very good with the company providing you with all the goods needed to execute your position.

title: Great environment to work in.
content: Great environment to work in. Amazing people. The benefits you get are worth doing your best while working here. Be aware that some positions are contract based. Do not expect to be hired permanently for those positions. No matter how long you've been there. The only downside I had was getting used to the pressure of the environment. It's a fun easy going atmosphere, yes. But there is also pressure to get work done as fast as possible. Strive for excellence in all things and you'll succeed.

title: Great workplace environment
content: Great workplace environment. Everyone is treated as an operator owner in that as long as you get your work done, no one is there to tell you when to arrive/leave/eat/take a break.

title: Great Place to work and great culture
content: *Learnt a lot both in terms of IT Management and Technical *Became an expert Oracle Apps DBA *Implemented EBS in 3 different countries *Managed a larger IT staff from different faculties *Was very respected as both Technical and Leadership candidate *Great culture overall *Very tight and close IT -very tight IT shop with very little resources -lot more work than resources -Huge work-life balance impact -Some executive management decisions were not good.

title: Great
content: I was a wonderful experience. I would recommend this company to anyone. I learned a great deal during my time at Activision and I hope to work with them again.

title: Productive and fun workplace. Charitable.
content: After working for Activision Blizzard for ten years, I learned that I could work anywhere. The mentality is either sink or swim at the organization. This approach made me learn quicker by being thrown into the fire with minimal support. It helped me to adapt to difficult situations and plan ways to overcome obstacles. I took initiative by stepping up and taking action without being asked. I tried to look for opportunities to make a difference and see where I can help my team. I would think outside the box and go beyond traditional approaches to see results or solve the problem.

title: Productive Workspace with Great Coworkers
content: Working at Activision has offered numerous opportunities for growth and development, whether that be mental, emotional, internal, or educational. Management has a good balance of strictness and flexibility. The coworkers, as well as the environment, offered a workspace that was energetic, enjoyable, and a very positive work environment.

title: Great job awesome people
content: Great job good pay, long hours with alot of breaks, great enviroment, sad that it is only temporary. i would live there if i could

title: A very fun workplace
content: I felt like I was a kid again, since there were video games everywhere and I was apart of a team that was amazing, we put the games together for game testers. They provided great food for free for whoever worked on the weekends. Great place.

title: Very fun workplace, but very bad management
content: Working in Activision was very fun due to the diversity of its people, countless languages and cultures. The downside of working in Activision is that it is absolutely impossible to advance in this company, as all contracts are temporary only. Regardless of how much work an individual puts in, it all comes down to the bias opinion of the manager whether you are worth keeping around or not.

title: Good work environment for a short term job
content: Job was contract based for a short term project. Informal atmosphere for game testers. Immediately had to start 12 hour shifts, 6 days a week after hiring, overtime pay included.

title: very fast production lines
content: great place to work. although the labor was under pay for employees to be working at a fast production line. only one shift per day. everyone gets the same break time.

title: Amazing work place!
content: I dedicated a lot of my time working at Blizzard, it is a fantastic company to work for. A great work environment, with a lot of highly skilled individuals who are looking to make an impact in the industry!

title: A workplace full of different types of energy and characters.
content: The time of the day is free, do as you please as long as you finish a reasonable amount of work. The hardest part was getting through the 12 hours a day 7 days a week, but your co-workers are there to push your through the day. Its not as bad when you connect with the people around you. Management is great, the senior testers are on the floor with QA testers to help with any issue, the leads try to help you with as much as they can and give out tasks to do for the day. Head managers also try to keep everyone posted about any events or changes to anything. You go in as co-workers, but leave the project as a family.
cons: 12 hours a day, 7 days a week

title: Great Environment, just wish Management wasn't all about the numbers
content: Blizzard Activision is an amazing place to work, and I will never regret my time there. Typical day was log in, take tickets, log into web-chat, take LOTS of tickets, log into phones, take calls. Lunch Back on to the queue, take more tickets. Go home.
cons: Management support. Over the years its become "WORK FASTER! Give better service. WORK FASTER!"

title: Great team and fun, challenging work
content: I will always remember my time at Activision fondly. From my very first day there I knew I would fit right in. There is always a great atmosphere in the office and there's a really satisfying team spirit. The work can be challenging at times, and repetitive at others. All in all, a great place to work.
cons: Pay could be a little higher

title: Great place to work but long hours and stressful
content: Work usually runs from 9 AM to 5 AM during winter and early spring. From late spring the hours run anywhere from 7 AM to 12 AM. Days are usually long and stressful. The beginning of the day consists of me reviewing over my emails from developers, productions, management and outsource QA. From there I sort out what has been completed the day prior and hand out any test case that still needs to be done to my QA testers as well as go over any major issues that still needs further investigation. At the end of the day, I go over all issues that were submitted to developers and email any major issues as a priority to management and production. I've learned to manage my work as well as my testers and be able to prioritize the importance of what issues need to be addressed first as opposed to less sever issues. Management was great to work with. Being formed QA testers themselves, they knew what everyone was going through so they were never too hard on the employees. Testers and fellow QA Leads were all a pleasure to work with. Everyone was always helpful and willing to give advice on work. The hardest part of the job is the stress of having a deadline. What I miss the most is the camaraderie I built with my fellow employees.
pros: Free dinner, great teamwork, great work environment

title: It was an ok job
content: If you like a fast pace and hot working environment then this isn't such a bad place to work at. Management isn't all that great. There is a lot of favoritism there.
pros: friendly co worker and over time

title: Fast pace interactive environment
content: * Rewarding * Communication, storyboarding * Smart, forward looking, leaders, * Fun, family oriented, supportive, collaborative * Short product lifecycles, ever changing industry dynamics * Approved recommendations, special projects, the people
pros: Work with the best in the industry

title: Very amazing and exciting work environment
content: Activision is an amazing company to work for. My co-workers are very passionate and are very hard workers all year around. The leads and bosses are great people as well, always try their best to keep spirits high and a healthy work environment for everyone.
pros: Free food occasionally, coffee, cheap vending machines.
cons: Long work hours during the summer

title: great experience
content: It was a fast paced workplace, strict on their rules for obvious reasons. I have learned enough from this company to become a strong warehouse worker that I see myself being. Management does what they have to do to make deadlines, coworkers do what they are told. There is no time for anything but working, walk in expecting to work and work hard.

title: A cool worlplace, perfect for a first job experience in a multinational company
content: Satisfaction Dublin is very nice place to work for, with a strong multicultural environment. Here you can meet a lot of people freshly arrived in Dublin and looking for first work experience. Gaming culture is very strong inside the office and you learn a lot about QA process, mostly the localization part. Work hours and overtime are frequent while approaching deadlines and employers are asked to be flexible to work on weekends when needed.

title: Productive
content: Fast paced management was easy to get along with co-workers had a good attitude most enjoyable part of my job was working with new people daily

title: Fun place to work with free games
content: Fun place to work. People thought it was just playing video games all day but there is so much more to it. Typical day was playing a game you were assigned and a certain task was given to you to make sure the game worked properly. If there was something wrong with the game you were to submit a report to a online database.

title: Productive
content: ~Standing for 8 hours straight. ~Making sure you don't fall behind because you well hold up the line. ~Co-workers will hate you even if you dont know who they are.

title: Marketing Intern
content: I always went to work smiling. At first, didn´t like video games but because of the job, I love them. I´m a very passionate girl. At Activision, I learnt how to make internal & external reports, how to decide events strategies, to localize assets and provide other departments with the information. My team mates were always great and we helped each other a lot. Maybe the most complicated stuff in this kind of jobs is the pressure but I try to count nearly always 10 before making a decision. And, finally, what I most enjoyed was that every day I learnt something new. It was great getting home with stories to tell.

title: So fun it barely feels like work!
content: Long hours spent staring at screens and sitting in a chair but a overall really positive experience. Working here made you feel integral to the process of developing a game and making something millions of people will enjoy. It made playing games all day feel vastly important. The only downside to this job were the hours that changed a lot based on the need to achieve certain milestones and release a finished product by a set date.
pros: Free video games, shirts, Activision products and the ability to play games before release
cons: Long shifts that changed constantly depending on what needed to be done.

title: great work place
content: great inviroment freindly people quick pase work.i learned alot about prodution line work there and about the video game industry

title: Activision Blizzard
content: Activision Blizzard was an amazing environment to work in and i got a lot of experience in QA Testing and Bug writing. I was dedicated in working long hours to get the project done and it was well worth it to see the final thing.

title: A valuable experience but long hours, which is standard in the video-game industry
content: An enjoyable workplace with great management. This job is not for everyone as the workweek can exceed 80 hours per week and pay is hourly but if you have a passion for video games this can be a great introduction.

title: Video Games
content: Being able to purchase games discounted is a plus Met wonderful lifelong friends Group environment is a great at making someone a team player

title: A fun and energetic place with great people
content: Demonware is a lovely place to work with nice people. Great benefits and bonuses company's culture is key to it's success
pros: free lunches, yoga, breakfast on certain days, fruit, employee game order store
cons: depending on time of year lovely place to work with nive people long hours

title: stressful because there was many different gang members so it was also seemed to have alot of tension in the place
content: Only a temporary job but we got a ton of hours! that was a huge plus! if I wasn't getting over 40 hours I probably wouldn't have stayed because there was a lot of different types of people but also gang members with tattoos so there was a lot of words exchanged and dirty looks all day long. very uncomfortable.

title: You work in the game industry
content: I took a job here as a tester to get my foot in the door after moving to California and previously working as an assistant producer at another game studio. Once hired you are only looked up as your position and previous work experience means nothing. The quality assurance testers are the lowest of the low and were referred to as the monsters in the basement. Overtime would be required without notice and the pay was so poor, nobody minded working the overtime. Moving up or getting hired on full time felt like complete luck and the vast majority of quality assurance testers were kept as temp employees for years non stop. My goal after working here was to move up in the industry till I was an executive, because I wanted to change the industry for the better and treat all my employees fairly and with respect. I would still approve of the CEO because he does make smart business decisions, I just think he doesn't know or care about how his lower employees are treated.
pros: We would get a free copy of the games we worked on, we would get discarded magazines, and occasionally ice cream (after the rest of the company got theres first).
cons: The treatment of the quality assurance employees.

title: Fun work environment
content: Great place to work! Benefit package is great, and the coworkers are awesome. Free game! Exciting work events. Game nights every other Wednesday and Thursday

title: Work place with a lot of room for personal growth.
content: Great place to work. Everyone works hard and makes sure that you get the work done and achieve what they ask of you. Great managers who really care about your growth.

title: Seasonal job
content: This was a seasonal job during the christmas times and here I would answer phone calls from clients that purchased games from Activition and help them with default products. I leard to just stay calm here and treat people with kindness
cons: A lot of over time which is no issue

title: It is a Fortune-100 best employer company
content: It is a fun place to work and express my talents. People there can really help you learn something. It is a typical American style base in Shanghai with casual but effective working environment.

title: Just typical production job
content: Very fast paced environment for work. very strict management and all about numbers. mostly hire temp staff and no benefits and work -life balance

title: A video gamers paradise!!!
content: The co workers are awesome, management really tests you and brings out the best in you. Activision really makes you want to strive to be better. Everyday I was there, I was smiling the whole time, alot of perks, long breaks, and awesome hours.
pros: Perks, Video games, Friends, and a ALOT OF HOURS.
cons: You start off as a contract worker.

title: productive fun workplace
content: a typical day consists of fast paced production line work where I learned multiple useful warehouse tips. Although management was a bit weak I enjoyed working for the company

title: If the Republican Party ran a company
content: Overall I loved my time with Activision. If you want to work in the big time of gaming and pull off some amazingly cool projects it can be done here if you work for it. Lots of resources all around you to do great work. And that is kinda the rub. Management is very layered. I needed to be a politician and an internal propagandist to get things done, because so many people need to be brought into the loop to approve any one project. Management philosophy is also very Republican and most of the top brass are big GOPers. Very what have you done for me lately environment with little loyalty shown to employees. Pay is good, but the healthcare plan, 401K are not up to par. Bonus plans are very unfair depending on what section of the business you work in. Ultimately this place will chew you up and spit you out. You'll just hopefully will have done some cool work in the process.

title: Best Job I have ever held, contract positions for the most part.
content: Great job, room to grow if you are willing to put the time in. Testing games making sure they function and they have met all of the first party standards.
cons: low pay hard to stay to get anywhere in the company

title: Publishing Company
content: Fun work environment with personal benefits. Work hours were long and compensation was undesirable.

title: An experience which taught me a lot and has never been frustrating.
content: Most of my professional experience is based on my 7 months job as a QA tester for Activision Dublin, where i learned and developed good skills in the QA department and where i was able to discover my best attributes in a work environment. As a QA tester i learned everything about the QA process and developed skills in some of the most important softwares in the videogame industry (Jira, for example), i also worked on franchises which are among the top tier in the industry, like Call of Duty (and it's last incarnation: Advanced Warfare) and Skylanders. As for the attributes which make me a good choice as an employee, i would like to focus on three of them: commitment, team work and resiliency. Team work is usually essential, and my experience made me learn what's the best way of doing it; working together for a higher purpose, a perfect service for the final user, i feel like commitment is one of the most important attributes when the job is a service i'm giving, the service has to be the best i can give and i've always been ready to work harder, overtime and under pressure, and that's where resiliency come into play; putting everything i have on a project and be ready to start once again the day after.

title: Very productive and enjoyable work place.
content: Typical work day would include productivity, meaning not very much time to stand around. I learned patience is a virtue when trying to handle work at a rapid pace, the management at Activision was superb. Our "line leads" were helpful when we had a tough time getting our coordination down. The toughest part overall in my opinion, was the speed in which we had to perform our tasks, but as I previously stated the management were always willing to help. The most enjoyable part of my time working at Activision would have to be the people and the environment, everyone was such a pleasure to be around.

title: Seriously, look for another place.
content: I worked in Distribution, which is literally the hardest work you could do at the company. Unloading trucks in 100+ degree weather, with someone higher up than you, watching you, always telling you to work harder and faster. Extremely disrespectful. Got almost no representation with my complaints, and I don't even think my complaints were reviewed. I will never come back to this place ever. Just not worth killing yourself, working, to make someone else rich. Management and office people seem to look down upon those who actually do the hard work, and are extremely ungrateful. A specific incident, is when I first started there, I was listening to my ipod in the breakroom, and the Production supervisor makes a big stink about not having electronics at work, which was totally understandable. Later that day, I see him on his phone, which since he's a supervisor, he's allowed to have, but here's the kick, he was on Facebook. Not anywhere related to work, yet he gets away with it. The only good thing that I got out of this job, was making friends with the people I directly worked with on a daily basis. I hope they find better jobs as well as myself. I also got forklift certified, but it conveniently only applies towards their company. The people in charge of this company obviously have never heard the term: Never tell somebody to do something you aren't willing to do yourself.
cons: Disrespectful office help. Disorganized hiring and lay off timing. Double standards.

title: Great place to work if you enjoy video games.
content: A typical day was going in and testing skylanders,which was a video game for xbox,playstation and wii councel.Making sure the correct quanity was received and the items worked properly. I also checked the cover of the games to make sure the color and wording was correct. There was a small group of us that did Quality Control of only 6 I did not find anything hard about that job at all I enjoyed it and the people I worked with. The most enjoyable part was working with all the new games that came out and also the other co-workers.

title: Sales Associate
content: Selling cars was a new experience for me, something I never thought I would see myself doing. I loved the job, and I regret leaving, but at the time I thought I was going to be able to go back to school and finish my degree. This job required a lot of my time and school didn't really work with my schedule, looked for something more part time and ended up leaving.

title: Its a good Organization to work with to have challenging work and Career Growth
content: Its a good Organization to work with to have challenging work and Career Growth

title: it was a ok place to work
content: we loaded and unloaded video games for shipping to stores and it was a team environment and i like working there it just wasn't stable

title: Productive and fun work place working with friendly people.
content: I like working at Activision Blizzard. It's a fun and productive work place. This company is through Placement Pro Temporary Agency. I work there not too long and got lay off. If they ever need me to go back work there, i diffidently will go back to work for them.

title: fun culture long hours
content: it can be a fun place to work esp. if you are into video games, but there's very little if any work/life balance and promotions/salary changes are not fair nor consistent. management does not exemplify great values and very little in way of career advancement/development.

title: Great Management, Great Products
